graziaxx.mainText5:
Primary Sources (Originals of the time):

  1. Official and Administrative Documentation:

    • Proclamations and Decrees of the Assunteria di Sanit√† and the Bolognese Senate (starting from 1628, for the management of the contagion, the measures adopted and the organization of services). Most of these documents are kept in the State Archives of Bologna.

    • Registers of the Dead and Burials (for data on victims, mortality peaks and mass graves).

    • Expenditure Statements (for the sums allocated to the poor, to the medical police, to the emptying of houses and to the management of the lazarettos).

    • Contemporary chronicles and official reports (for example, the report by Pietro Moratti ‚Äì Account of the orders and provisions made in the lazarettos in Bologna and its County during the contagion of the Year 1630).

  2. Artistic and Votive Testimonies:

    • The Plague Altarpiece by Guido Reni (1630): direct testimony of the civic vote and religious devotion.

    • The Votive canopy from 1634 (used in thanksgiving processions).

    • Paintings and Ex-Votos (such as the anonymous Bolognese painting on the plague in Via San Mamolo, often cited in secondary sources).

Secondary Sources (Subsequent historical studies):

  1. Specific historical studies on Bologna and the plague of 1630:

    • Historical demography studies that have elaborated data on deaths and population (e.g. Marco Poli, author of studies on epidemics in Bologna, or older demographic studies such as those of P.L. Da Gatteo and A. Brighetti).

    • Monographs and essays that reconstruct the spread, the health management (the role of Cardinal Bernardino Spada and the Camillians) and the social consequences of the epidemic.

  2. General Historical Context:

    • Sources that deal with the War of Succession of Mantova and the passage of the Lansquenets, responsible for the spread of the contagion throughout northern Italy (as also mentioned in The Betrothed by Alessandro Manzoni, which, although not a primary historical source for Bologna, bears witness to the general context of the 1630 epidemic in northern Italy)

lastre.mainText1: These are the oldest house numbers in the city. They were introduced at the end of the 18th century, when Bologna was under Napoleonic rule, to better organize the postal service and city management.
lastre.mainText2: Before then, houses didn't have numbers, and people sometimes oriented themselves by the description of the facade or the name of the family who lived there. The sandstone tiles, which you still find today, are a testament to this change.
lastre.mainText3: Many of those you see are terracotta and have been made over the centuries, sometimes replacing the original ones. While terracotta tiles were easier to mass-produce, the engraving on the stone was a craft that demonstrates the importance and durability these urban signs were intended to provide.
lastre.mainText4: The presence of these sandstone numbers is a testament to tangible evidence of the city's evolution and the traditional materials used over the centuries.
lastre.mainText5: At number 11 on Via Tanari Vecchia, we find a sandstone plaque bearing the number 1202 (an even number), while the current number is 11 (an odd number), being on the right in the direction of increasing numbers, as required by current toponymy regulations.

chiesasbene.mainText5:
Historical Sources for the Church of San Benedetto

 

  1. Sources of Toponymy and Urban History of Bologna:

    • Archives and Studies on the History of Via Indipendenza: These documents (often linked to the State Archives or the Archiginnasio Library) are crucial for precisely dating the great transformation of 1892, the year in which the church was "turned" and the facade reoriented to face the newly created Via Indipendenza.

    • Studies on the Churches of Bologna: Academic texts and monographs that attest to their origins in the 13th century and the subsequent reconstruction in the 17th century (dated 1606), specifying the role of the architect Giovanni Battista Ballerini.

  2. Sources of the History of Art and Architecture of Bologna:

    • Art Guides and Catalogues: For the list of internal works and artists. These sources confirm the presence of paintings by masters of the Baroque and Mannerist periods, such as Giacomo Cavedoni, Alessandro Tiarini and Lucio Massari.

    • Texts on Religious Complexes: To identify the Order that managed it, namely the Mini Friars of San Francesco di Paola (the "Paolotti").

  3. Institutional Sites and Cultural Portals (Web):

    • Official Tourism and Culture Portals of the Municipality of Bologna (e.g. Bologna Welcome or History and Memory of Bologna): These sites summarize and validate the key historical data (13th century, 17th century reconstruction, late 19th century reorientation) Nineteenth century) for public use.

In summary, the information comes from the concordance of data present in historical archives, art history studies and institutional sources that trace the evolution of this important Bolognese place of worship.

chiesapioggia.mainText5:
Public and institutional sources on the history and places of worship in Bologna:

  • Official Tourism and Culture Sites: such as Bologna Welcome and BolognaBO, which provide details on the location, opening hours and history of the church.
  • Online Encyclopedias and Historical Archives: such as Wikipedia and Bologna Online/Biblioteca Salaborsa, which offer insights into the 13th-century origins, the reconstruction, the miracle of the rain of 1561 which gave the Sanctuary its name, and the list of works of art housed there (such as those by Agostino Carracci, Francesco Monti, Ludovico Mattioli and Alfonso Lombardi).
  • Art Guides and Portals: which confirm the full names (Santuario della Madonna della Pioggia, Chiesa di Santa Maria della Pioggia and of San Bartolomeo di Reno) and the most important works of art.

These sources agree on key information regarding the location (at the intersection of Via Galliera and Via Riva di Reno), the original name (San Bartolomeo di Reno), and the double dedication following the miracle of the rain.

pioggia1.mainText1:
The Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia and San Bartolomeo di Reno (Via Riva di Reno, 124, corner of Via Galliera) in Bologna, houses the "Landscape with Bartolomeo" which is a work by the Bolognese painter Ludovico Mattioli.

üñºÔ∏è The "Landscape with San Bartolomeo" by Ludovico Mattioli

The work mentioned is located along the staircase leading to the upper rooms of the church and is not a painting by Annibale, as it is erroneously attributed to him, & nbsp; but by one of his successors of the Bolognese school.

< ul >
  • Artist: Ludovico Mattioli (1662-1747)
  • Title (probable): Landscape with Saint Bartholomew
  • Location:& nbsp;Staircase of the Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia and San Bartolomeo di Reno, Bologna.
  • Dating:& nbsp;18th century.

    • Historical and Artistic Context:

    < ul >
  • Landscape in the 18th century:& nbsp;Although Annibale Carracci was the pioneer of the "ideal landscape" in the 17th century, Ludovico Mattioli worked in a later period, the 18th century, where the landscape genre was now fully developed and autonomous. Mattioli, a Bolognese artist active between the end of the seventeenth century and the beginning of the eighteenth century, was known not only for his canvases but also as an engraver and a landscape painter . < /li>
  • Style: His landscapes are typical of the late Baroque and Rococo taste . Unlike the solemn and "heroic" nature of Annibale, Mattioli's works present a more pictorial, airy and less structured style , with a predilection for atmosphere and light effects . < /li>
  • The Church: The Sanctuary of the Madonna della Pioggia (or San Bartolomeo di Reno) has undergone numerous renovations over the centuries. The current church is mainly from the eighteenth century (rebuilt according to a design attributed to Alfonso Torreggiani), and works such as that of Mattioli fit into this eighteenth-century decorative context.< /li>
  • Iconography:& nbsp;The inclusion of St. Bartholomew, the martyred apostle, serves as a reference to the ancient dedication of the church and the adjoining hospice.< /li>

manifattura.mainText2:
Current Status and New Function

Today, the area of the former Manifattura is part of a major architectural and urban recovery project known as Manifattura delle Arti .

Cineteca di Bologna: The historic building on Via Riva di Reno is the current home of the Cineteca di Bologna , an internationally renowned cultural center for the preservation and promotion of cinema.

Gardens: Near the former Manifattura are also the Giardini ex Manifattura Tabacchi , a green area open to the public (generally from 7:00 am to 7:00 pm), often frequented by families and equipped with a play area for children.
manifattura.mainText3:
Links and Additional Content (Photos)

For photos, the best way is to consult online resources that document the historic building and the restoration projects:

Ex Reale Manifattura dei Tabacchi - Bologna Online : Often contains historical or current images of the building and its Art Nouveau facade.

Manifattura Tabacchi - History and Memory of Bologna : Another resource that documents the history and appearance of the place.

I particularly recommend that you look for images of the facade on Via Riva di Reno , which is the best preserved and most characteristic part of the Art Nouveau architecture.

If you're specifically interested in photographs taken inside abandoned areas before their redevelopment (often with an industrial archaeology feel), you should look for exhibitions or projects like the one mentioned in the article: "Spazi vicini. Ex Manifattura Tabacchi. Percorso fotografico verso il recupero" by Ivano Adversi .
